lexUnit.name: rise.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to move in an upward direction

sentence.text: The sun rose smoky red behind ugly rips of dark cloud and she sighed .
The helicopter rose six feet into the air , tilted forward to gain airspeed , and buried its nose-wheel in the ground .
The water rises 12 metres as the tide is forced into the funnel of the Severn estuary and into the Avon river .
The highest land is only 2 metres above sea level and even this would be exposed to storm surges if mean sea level rose by 1 metre .
Then the balloons were off rising above Herefordshire to eleven and a half thousand feet instead of the planned ten and a half thousand .
These bare poles are all that remains of the jungle that the lake drowned as the waters rose behind the dam .
The plane rises unsteadily into the air .
Steam rises off the ground , drying the fields as the morning sun tackles the night 's cold dew .
Nothing was left but a clearing in the forest and a flock of doves who rose up into the air , wheeled round , and flew off .
In 1923 , Turkey broke away from the tired Ottoman rulers , and Kemal Ataturk rose to power on a wave of popular support .
Inevitably , some people will get burned in the process , but others will rise triumphantly from the fray to even greater successes .
